title: Will Paulo Guedes cease to be Brazil's Minister of the Economy before 1 December 2020?
preds:
Neither plagues nor scandals will topple Brazil’s populist president - The Economist
https://www.economist.com/the-world-ahead/2020/11/17/neither-plagues-nor-scandals-will-topple-brazils-populist-president
Tue, 17 Nov 2020 00:00:00 GMT

Flip-flop situation. Bolsonaro popularity falling in Sao Paulo, the nation's finanial powerhouse. But dismissing former "superminister" Guedes by 1 Dec will please neither the military faction of the government, who are now at loggerheads with "the captain" due to his showing disrespect for certain active and reserve general officers,  nor the so-called Olavista faction of "Bolsonarismo" who say they like "free market" solutions.

Brazil economy staging solid 'V-shaped' recovery, job growth strong - Guedes - Reuters
https://www.reuters.com/article/brazil-economy-guedes-idUSS0N2GS004
Thu, 29 Oct 2020 14:44:19 GMT Analysis: Brazil economy facing stimulus drought as monetary, fiscal taps run dry - Reuters
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-economy-stimulus-analysis-idUSKBN27E2IU
Thu, 29 Oct 2020 15:31:00 GMT

The latest big idea of the superminister Guedes, to privatize the national health service known by acronym SUS, was made into a decree by The Captain, presidente Bolsonaro.  The presidential decree was published in the National Journal and became instant law.  But since the state of the brand of the current regime does not inspire or attract foreign capital, the government revoked the presidential decree less than 16 hours later, not done by the Captain himself, but in a special edition of the National Journal, as if his communications team thought that that would shield the president (who is not a member of a political party) from any political blowback.  Inflation is now around 3 percent (some say 2.2 percent) with food prices (including shortages of rice and soy) shooting up.  This all sugests that Guedes may exit state right, particularly if Biden wins the US presidency.  Here is a link from UOL in Brazilian portuguese  https://economia.uol.com.br/colunas/carla-araujo/2020/10/28/sus-pressao-bolsonaro-revoga-decreto-derrota-guedes-ppi.htm

-1% per week. Also, some positive headlines: Brazil to join OECD in a year: economy minister Guedes - Reuters
https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-economy-guedes/brazil-to-join-oecd-in-a-year-economy-minister-guedes-idUSKBN2751W3
Tue, 20 Oct 2020 13:52:00 GMT Guedes Signs An Agreement to Finance US Exports to Brazil that May Reach US $ 1 billion - Folha de S.Paulo
https://www1.folha.uol.com.br/internacional/en/business/2020/10/guedes-signs-an-agreement-to-finance-us-exports-to-brazil-that-may-reach-us-1-billion.shtml
Wed, 21 Oct 2020 17:30:00 GMT Brazil's economy on track to shrink 4% this year: Economy Minister Guedes - Reuters
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-economy-guedes-idUSKBN2741XV
Mon, 19 Oct 2020 14:30:00 GMT Truce Between Brazil’s Economy Chief and Congress Lifts Real - Bloomberg
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-05/brazil-s-economy-chief-and-lower-house-speaker-try-to-make-peace
Mon, 05 Oct 2020 07:00:00 GMT EMERGING MARKETS-Latam FX rises; Real extends gains on U.S.-Brazil trade optimism - Reuters
https://www.reuters.com/article/emerging-markets-latam-idUSL1N2HB0V4
Tue, 20 Oct 2020 14:30:00 GMT
Going to a soft round number on this one.

Guedes takes extra salary of R $ 21 thousand from Marinho with Bolsonaro endorsement
 Since March, the government has not published on the Transparency Portal the super salaries of ministers such as Marinho, Onyx and Tarcísio Freitas

as we are nearing the deadline I am decreasing the probability.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-economy-guedes-idUSKCN25D2PD

Now that Bolsonaro's #2 man in the Senate was caught by the cops hiding thousands of riais in his undies that he ripped off on a Covid-19 scam, and is apprently going to resign as part of The Captain's "team"  it will make the leader and his family look bad to make his "super minister" walk the plank before Christmas time, altough there are plenty of reasons for him to be given the hook.
Dropping as I don't hear anything.
Decreasing due to passage of time and no new news.
Bolsonaro seems to be buying what Guedes is selling for now [1] [1] https://oglobo.globo.com/economia/bolsonaro-paulo-guedes-o-cara-da-politica-economica-palavra-final-dele-1-24672082

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-04/brazil-house-speaker-says-ties-with-economy-minister-are-cut
If austerity is totally scrapped then Guedes will quit. Watch for signs of that.
Moving closer to the average of the crowd to hedge a little

Economy Minister Paulo Guedes was talking about 'alternative taxes' when he was interrupted by Minister Luiz Eduardo Ramos and government leader in the Chamber, Ricardo Barros, and led away from journalists. That is General Ramos.
Actually I think staying at 5% implies too large a probability that Guedes' tax agenda will be the catalyst for his leaving, so I will lower a bit here.

Would normally decrease with passage of time, but Guedes is looking to speed up tax reform (https://news.bloombergtax.com/daily-tax-report-international/brazils-guedes-seeks-support-for-tax-on-transactions), which could cause some friction with Bolsonaro. As such, I'll stay at 5% for now.

Since 1985, the average term of minister of the economy in Brazil is about one year (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Economy_(Brazil)) It seems to me that changing minister of the economy is a pretty frequent issue in Brazil and not as big of a deal as it is compared to more stable, developed countries. Paulo Guedes has been in office since last January, so it not impossible that he will leave/get replaced based on this base rate. Assuming that he will follow his precedent ministers' destiny and leave the office in one year, the probability that he leaves/gets replaced in the next two months is around 15%.  If I were wrong, it is most likely to be a result of the unpredictability of geopolitics events. There might be some rumors that people inside Brazil will know, but I will not know by searching on Google. There could also be some more aggressive spending plans designed by the president and worsen the relationship between the president and the minister.  During COVID-19, there has been a growing disagreement between the President and Guedes on big government spending. Since two major figures have already left, it seems like there is still a lot of volatility in Guedes position. Based on this fact, I adjust the probability of him being replaced to be 20%. There have been rumors of potential candidates replacing Guedes since a month ago. However, the person involved quickly dismissed this rumor. Since then, the president and Guedes have been having much less public disagreement (source: https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2020/09/03/brazils-president-and-his-economy-minister-start-to-disagree). Since replacing a government official doesn't seem to be very hard in Brazil, the fact that the president has not done it yet makes me suspect that they might have entered some sort of agreement to stop fighting. Thus, I readjust the probability to be 15%.

Even if I am 2* times more pessimistic than the crowd I feel uncomfortable, the situation is really unstable in Brasil and increase my forecast to 15  [1] https://www.migalhas.com.br/quentes/333544/paulo-guedes---de--posto-ipiranga--ao-balanca-mas-nao-cai
Quite likely. Guedes has recently lost two senior officials, & his plans for an enhanced social welfare programme (Rendo Brasil) have been rejected by Pres Bolsonaro

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-cenbank-idUSKBN25L01R
He called public servants parasites and was fined for it. Keeping it high awhile longer. He might hang-on but presently appears sidelined.

Using crowd forecast pushed up by a percent. Article below points at some conflict, although doesn't seem like Guedes ceasing his position is likely. https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-brazil-economy-guedes-analysis/brazils-guedes-finds-influence-waning-as-bolsonaro-takes-up-spending-reins-idUKKBN26735I

Learning Portuguese is helpful in connection with this forecasting problem.  Here's another reason why... link  https://noticias.uol.com.br/colunas/reinaldo-azevedo/2020/09/17/tchau-guedes-seu-chefe-tem-seus-proprios-sonhos-de-ruina-ou-teto-desaba.htm Former ambassador to Brazil and Undersecretary of State, Tom Shannon, (whose Wikipedia bio tags him as a Democrat) will be doing a Zoom webinar with the CEBRI (Brazil International Relations Council) on the 24th, that might offer some helpful context.
Revision based on reports that new rifts are forming between Bolsonaro and Guedes, manifesting in the sudden ceasing of one of Guedes' projects.

Increasing based on potential disagreements between bolsonaro and guedes. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-politics/brazils-bolsonaro-scraps-new-welfare-plan-economy-minister-plays-down-rift-idUSKBN2662M6

Blosonaro has publicly revoked some of Guedes' power, killing the project that Guedes had been working on and one of his main reasons for staying(https://uk.reuters.com/article/brazil-economy-guedes/analysis-brazils-guedes-finds-influence-waning-as-bolsonaro-takes-up-spending-reins-idUKL8N2G7042). As  such, i have to revise my forecast upwards a bit.

Following recent noise about the relationship between Mr Guedes and Mr Bolsonaro (thanks @kramlal and @ConnorTB for the articles) 
-> Bolsonaro rejected and critized  Economy Minister Paulo Guedes’ strategy (more preciselt Rodrigues)  to finance the program by redirecting money away from other social initiatives
 I update slightly my base rate. Following the same logic than for my first forecat (decomposition of the problem between  he resigned before Dec 1st and he is fired by Bolosonaro) I am going to increase probabilities of the 2 buckets respectively to 7% and 4%. I still think that 
- The two major figures who left the cabinet were people who were closely linked to Bolsonaro's decisions related to their field. The disagreement between Bolosonaro and Guedes on economy is more subtle.
- If Mr  Bolsonaro fires Mr Guedes, it will impact massively the stock market as international investors trust Mr Guedes
- Mr Guedes is an educated economic liberal with no future political ambition. He does not need to disaffiliate himself from Bolsonaro's balance sheet in order to protect his future.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-politics/brazils-bolsonaro-scraps-new-welfare-plan-economy-minister-plays-down-rift-idUSKBN2662M6
https://www.bloombergquint.com/politics/bolsonaro-doesn-t-want-to-hear-about-his-own-social-plan-anymore

Bolsonaro just killed the major project that Guedes had been working on and, in so doing, publicly criticized the way that Guedes handled the project. As this was one of my reasons for Guedes remaining, I am revising my forecast upward.  Obviously, it's still super unlikely that Guedes resigns. This seems to be the most isolated he has ever been in the administration, but he has had several showdowns with Bolsonaro before and has remained in his position through all of them.  That being said, I think this suggests that the original source of conflict between Bolsonaro and Guedes has not been resolved. I think it is unlikely, but I would not be surprised if Guedes decides that he's lost the war over fiscal policy and that, especially in a post-pandemic world, there's not much of a point in sticking around.  I really don't know what the right probability should be, but I think today's probability should be higher than yesterday's forecasts and lower than the forecasts a few weeks ago.

Hattip @Rickburger for analysis and reference as I don't read Portuguese I depend on other's analysis. There are 2-1/2 months left, I'll raise the probabilty a bit, but this seems like one more confrontation, may not be the end of the line.
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages. But I'm staying steady on this question.

Bolsonaro has just vetoed a pet Guedes project called Ïncome Brazil  ("Renda Brasil") that was supposed neoliberal substitute to replace the Bolsa Familia (economic bootstrap for the poor and marginalizd that was a bread and butter vote getter for the Worekers Party (PT) throughout poor Northeastern Brasil and the border provinces that butt up against Peru, Colombia, Venezuela, French territoire of Guyane, Suriname etc.  Renda Brazil woud reduce benefits to the poor and disabled by half, and finance the most recent el cheapo effort of the Friedmantes to play "lets go slumming" with budget cuts at other ministries that are held by political lackeys- not a smooth move because Bolsonaro is a leader without a party (unless you consider his parties to be Facebook and Twitter platforms) and he brought them on for their support and the moolah and they don't take kindly to getting their points shaved.  This fiasco connected with Guedes' Superministry is viewed one more time by the captain's praetorian guard as not respecting the chain of command.  Since Bolsonaro glommed onto the Bolsa Familia and the easy money it provides to the marginalized, and the welfare fraudsters imbedded among them, his populacrity in those regions has increased and the PT and their "leftist" cohorts are on the slippery slope.  The deputy minster who helped Guedes develop Renda Brasil,  is now in the "fritura" process, and his days are  numbered. The question now becomes when the captain finally gives Guedes the hook.  Link in Brazilian Portuguese  https://www1.folha.uol.com.br/mercado/2020/09/bolsonaro-veta-desindexacao-e-sinaliza-novo-golpe-a-agenda-de-guedes.shtml

Upping prediction given the recent reports of Bolsonaro not being able to find an agreement with Guedes over deficit in order to fund Renda Brasil. This is yet another signal of controversy mounting, and I believe I was underestimating Guedes's probability of resigning before today.
Mantaining forecast for the week. Interesting to see that the aggregate has gone 10->5% in a couple of days.

Bringing back prediction to 9% after recent bill was rejected by Bolsonaro and Guedes needed to defend that this was not targeting him, but the bill itself.
https://blinks.bloomberg.com/news/stories/QGPHMT073NCW
Decay of forecast with time and lack of material news
Updated based on passage of time

As @cls stated, Guedes's proposal was accepted by Bolsonaro on a recent bill, which may indicate that there is not much conflict there. Also passage of time with no new rumors on Guedes's resignation (or forced replacement) lead me to adjust downwards.
Dropping as time continues / skewing based on crowd prediction.
Adjusting downwards after budget was passed successfully and on the back of @cls comment
Assume inertia continues doing what it does best.
Share much of the same logic as my teammates. I also buy the argument by @cls that the lack of major news recently lowers the probability that Guedes will be replaced.
Likelihood reducing as we get closer to settlement, and with now dramatically different updates coming out of Brazil than before.

I slowly decrease my probability now because no major news. On google news there are few articles but mainly in Portuguese and more in favor of Guedes staying For instance in [1], President Jair Bolsonaro complied with the recommendation of Minister Paulo Guedes and vetoed a provision that granted amnesty in taxes to be paid by churches in the country, a measure that could have an impact of R $ 1 billion. The veto, which may be overturned by Congress, was signed on Friday, the deadline for sanctioning the proposal, and will be published in the "Official Gazette" of this Monday. With the measure, Bolsonaro meets Guedes, but dislikes one of the sectors that support his government. In the last few days, the evangelical group in the Chamber had been pressing to avoid the veto. [1]https://www.otempo.com.br/politica/bolsonaro-veta-perdao-a-dividas-de-igrejas-e-atende-a-paulo-guedes-1.2384809
My Probability dist had a peak around release of budget but with more time passing since it's release I'm reducing accordingly

We have a starting point base rate of 25% derived from historical changes within ministries. We then apply a bayesian approach here and question the current state of brazil's economy. With covid having been in effect for several months in Brazil and with Guedes still in office I think that lowers the chance he will cease to be minister by December 1. With 3 months left in effect I think the "chatter" would be worse by now but given that the worst has already occurred this lowers my prediction. Diminishing returns to figures leaving the office also supports my reasoning.

Lowering probability due to recently proposed bill that is in line with Guedes fiscal policy goals, while increasing the President's power over the public sector. https://in.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-economy-reform-idINKBN2602AD
Bolsonaro needs to keep him around as a scapegoat for when nothing gets better.   Could be close to 6 December, but I think after the first of the year instead.
Bolsonaro has removed Guedes from negotiating with their Congress on the economy and is moving at light speed away from Guedes austerity as Bolsonaro’s popularity declines. Will Guedes quit?
Team consensus + lack of recent speculation is good news for Guedes. only needs to survive 3 months!

Speculation surrounding a Guedes departure has died down quite a bit recently, and was perhaps a bit inflated due to health minister turnover in earlier stages of the Covid crisis. Moreover, given that he and Bolsonaro have made headway on certain policy disagreements, there doesn't seem to be much reason to expect his departure, and I don't want to be anchored to a higher-than-reasonable probability just because the question is being asked -- I agree with others who have said that it would take a fairly new, unexpected development for Guedes to leave at this point.

I think I'm ready to revise down my estimate. Based on recent news (translated with google lol), there have been no mentions of a possible Bolsonaro resignation in the past week or so, compared with several articles per week (in both American and Brazilian publications) at the height of the speculation. This would prompt me to lower my probability to (what I estimate to be) the base rate before the speculation began. I am further lowering the probability of resignation because Bolsonaro's popularity has continued to soar, making it very unlikely that he will shake things up and disrupt the market/economy by firing Guedes.
Resignation seems highly unlikely given Guedes has already confirmed he has no plans to do so. Agree with @dzhou3 and @vkasat logic to calculate the chance of Guedes getting dismissed.

There are 22 cabinet members, 2 of whom have left. Albeit recently, it is very important to note that Guedes himself has stated he has no intention of resigning. Thus, only  a large enough disagreement between Guedes and Bolsanaro can lead to Guedes being fired before December 1st.

There needs to be another catalyst in Brazilian politics for this to happen in my estimation. I do not think the current budget disagreements are enough to force a resignation. Given volatility in Brazilian politics over the past few years however, it would be naive to rule the scenario out completely.

There is a lot of public documentation of th erelationship between Guedes and Bolsonaro, but as @repstein rightly points out, there is little reason to assume that this 3 month stretch is going to be so dramatically different from the last three month stretch, such that Guedes would choose to quit. The argument can be made that given that he hasn't quit by now, if nothing material has changed about his position, it should be less likely that he quits in the next three months. Obviously, this forecast will have to be monitored/updated based on new information released.
Initial forecast based on team & crowd consensus - slightly extremized

At the time of this question's creation, Brazil was facing major struggles and criticisms on it's handling of the coronavirus situation. This resulted in the firing of Brazil's Health Minister. Shortly thereafter, the successor to the Health Minister position resigned four week later. Other members that have left Bolsonaro's cabinet include the Chief Justice Minister who resigned as a protest to Bolsonaro's firing the federal police chief. As @hermannviktor pointed out, these departures were due to catalysts in Brazillian politics, such as the coronavirus pandemic, and it is unclear what/when the next catalyst might be.  While there has been criticism on Guedes over his public spending policy, on August 17th, in an article by Reuters, it is stated by internal sources that Guedes does not intend to resign, nor is this being considered by the ministry or the central bank [1]. However I believe that if Bolsonaro and Guedes disagree enough on policies, this will lead to either the firing or resignation of Guedes.  In more recent news, dailytimes points out that the spending during coronavirus, controlled by Bolsonaro, has blown through the budget limits set by Guedes, and there has been clashes between Guedes and Bolsonaro over a spending policy around Bolsa Familia welfare program. I believe that if Bolsanaro and Guedes objectives become too misaligned, this can lead to Guedes' departure.  Sources
[1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-economy-guedes/brazil-economy-minister-paulo-guedes-not-about-to-resign-sources-idUSKCN25D2PD
[2] https://dailytimes.com.pk/663458/brazil-economy-outshines-mexico-after-surprise-role-reversal/
[3] https://pledgetimes.com/brazils-last-super-minister-tries-to-take-charge-of-the-budget-despite-bolsonaros-wear/

Baseline: So far 2 Health ministers, the Justice Minister and the Education Minister lost their position this year. Out of these 4 occurrences, 3 happened upon Bolsonaro's decision and 1 happened due to a scandal. Brazil has 16 cabinet members, thus so far around 1/4 of the cabinet has lost their position. However, we need to account for the fact that most of those happened amid turmoils in politics mainly due to Covid. Therefore, we need to try to predict how likely it is that there will be another catalyst in Brazilian politics that will make Guedes leave his position. Adjustments:
Covid:
The turmoil started in April, at a time when Covid has not hit Brazil yet. However, since then Brazil is among the countries hit hardest by the pandemic. This has shifted everyone's focus on the pandemic as opposed to Bolsonaro's changes in Brazilian politics.
Position:
The two major figures who left the cabinet were people who were closely linked to Bolsonaro's decisions related to their field (e.g. the Justice Minister left after there was a decision about Bolsonaro having more power on the legal system). However, there have been no major economic disagreements between Bolsonaro and his cabinet. Therefore, until there is no economic discrepancy between Bolsonaro and his cabinet, it is not unlikely that Guedes stays. Conclusion: As @pchi has pointed out in one of his links, there has been some disagreements between Bolsonaro and Guedes about the Brazilian budget due to the pandemic, which might be a catalyst in the future. However, we still don't see it very likely as of now that this issue would escalate until year end. The yearly budget will need to be approved for 2021, however this usually happens in the end of December, which, however, is out of the question's scope.

Looking at latest news regarding the stories the following links seem to have importance:
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-economy-guedes/brazil-economy-minister-paulo-guedes-not-about-to-resign-sources-idUSKCN25D2PD
https://www.ft.com/content/c63d45a1-8e79-42df-84a8-00f7b089ca88
https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2020/09/05/brazils-president-and-his-economy-minister-start-to-disagree This question thus seems to be a judge of credibility of the new sources. While sources say that Guedes has no intention to resign, it's worthwhile to consider historical changes in leadership in terms of the Minister of the Economy. Since 2015 there have been 5 changes in leadership, most of who lasted under 1yr as minister of economy. Guedes has been in charge since Jan 1, 2019 and has thus likely already developed substantial credibility as a result having not left his position yet.  Overall the trend from news seems like he will stay, but will have to pay attention to news from Brazil if any changes were to occur. Even though they had reached a "truce", it will be important to see if Guedes' disagreements with Bolsonaro escalate to anything further.

Base rate: I first looked at the rate of economy ministers that resigned but it was really high as they all finally resigned. So here for me the question is more on the date: December 1st. I do think the probability that Paulo Guedes resigns is high, estimated at 0.8. Now, the question is to estimate the probability that he will resign / be fired before Dec 1st. 
-	he resigned before Dec 1st Comparison with the 2 other cases: : Moro was the star of the Brazilian government because of the Car Wash investigation. He enjoys the support of the majority of Brazilians, more than Bolsonaro, whose popularity is in decline. Contrarily to Moro, Mr Guedes is an educated economic liberal with no future political ambition. He does not need to disaffiliate himself from Bolsonaro's balance sheet in order to protect his future. Regarding the health ministry, again the comparison does not make that much sense as Brazil was one of the countries was one of the countries worst affected by covid-19. It has had 4m confirmed cases largely on the president’s fault. Given this disastrous health results, it is unsurprising to see such unstability at health ministy. On the other hand, Salim Mattar, Brazil’s privatization secretary, and Paulo Uebel, the debureaucratisation secretary, walked out on August 11 after complaining about the lack of progress in the government’s economic agenda. At the time of the news Mr Guedes understood the sign of dissatisfaction as the trademark reforms had stumbled during the coronavirus crisis, but placing the blame on the “political establishment”. but it was already almost a month ago ans he is still here -> proba 15% [1]
-	he is fired by Bolsonaro: low probable 2% as it will impact massively the stock market as international investors trust Mr Guedes, no real rationale for this
[1] https://www.ft.com/content/c63d45a1-8e79-42df-84a8-00f7b089ca88

Let us break down the question into the following components: Will Guedes cease to be Brazil's Minister of the Economy and if so, will it happen before 1 December 2020. Yes, Guedes could simply resign and that appears the most likely reason he would leave given his division with the PM but there could be other factors for his departure as well (e.g. Bolsanaro just replaces him). Since Minister of the Economy Pedro Malan (I use him as a starting point since Minister of Economies before him served very short terms and would seem not to generate a reasonable base rate), only 1/6 Ministers of the Economy have resigned. Thus, we put the probability that Guedes leaves his position at slightly higher to adjust for other reasons for his "departure" -> 22%. Now determining his departure before 1 December 2020 is harder. At best I put this at 33% based on the news sentiment. Thus the probability that he leaves his position before 1 December 2020 becomes 7.26%.

Base rate for resigning, even under Bolsonaro's administration, is not particularly high. Bolsonaro and Guedes have had public clashes but nothing out of the ordinary for this administration. I think it is less likely that he will resign given that he has no future political ambitions, and this is a relatively short timeline for resigning. The other two cabinet members that resigned likely had catalysts due to COVID and other geopolitical events, but there does not seem to be another similar catalyst on the horizon.

As of now, doesn't seem likely that Guedes will step down. Although it seems like he has settled disagreement with Bolsonaro, it is worth noting that Guedes and Rodrigo Maia, the speaker of Brazil's lower house, have "cut ties". Thus, I believe there is a non-trivial chance of a resignation within the next few months. Source: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-04/brazil-house-speaker-says-ties-with-economy-minister-are-cut

Reasons he might resign: 
- There was significant speculation that he might resign after the previous resignations of two ministers in the administration. At most, it seemed like maybe a 1/3 chance of him resigning at the time. As mentioned in the articles, there is ongoing tension about the administration's economic policies. The president has extended significant social benefit programs in response to the coronavirus, but Guedes is a staunch UChicago school economist. He opposes any renewal of Brazil's previous proclivity for excessive spending. 
- He recently lost another battle to Bolsonaro on a matter relatively unrelated to the government's coronavirus response. At Guedes' request, the government freezed hiring for new positions (previously existing positions could still be filled). This was just lifted so Brazil's FBI and FDA could hire more investigators, among other new employees. This seems like the administration is kind of spitting in the fact of Guedes', as this policy change delivers him another defeat on a relatively unimportant issue. 
- Guedes' is the subject of an investigation into his dealings with pension funds. However, the investigation was opened in 2018 and there have been few, if any, developments since then. Also, Brazil's justice system moves relatively slowly. He would only be forced to leave if massive revelations came to light and the public demanded his ouster. Bolsonaro is also no friend of the justice system, and he is more likely than not to oppose any attempts by the justice department to intervene in his administration. 
- previous ministers of the economy have stayed in office for about 1 year on average. Guedes' is on the longer end of the typical range. That being said, it seems like ministers who are the first to fill their position in that administration stay longer than replacements.  Reasons he might stay: 
- Don't want to do too much psychological speculation, but he is not a politician, he's not affiliated with a political party, and he has no future political ambition. This makes Guedes far less likely to leave the administration than Sergio Moro, who seems to be positioning himself to run in the next election (he is younger and beloved by the public--so he may have wanted to distance himself from the unpopular Bolsonaro administration). In other words, this is the most important (and probably the last) job that Guedes will ever have. He seems more likely to leave out of principle than out of a fear that remaining in the administration would impact him in the future. 
- The worse the economic/public health situation gets in Brazil, the more likely it is that Guedes leaves. However, the coronavirus has slightly receded, the economy has improved (the Real and equity market are both up about 40% over the past few months), and Bolsonaro's popularity is at a recent high (his unfavorables have fallen by over 10 percent and his favorables have risen over 10% in this last month). 
- Guedes has suffered several major policy defeats over the past few months (he opposed the hiring un-freeze and, more notably, the renewal of Brazil's equivalent of the $600 stimulus checks), but he has remained in office nonetheless. There do not seem to be any major issues on the horizon that would bring his tensions will Bolsonaro to a "final showdown"--it appeared that the renewal of the stimulus checks was most likely to cause this, but that has now come and gone. 
- Firing Guedes would have a strong, negative impact on Brazil's stock market, as it would signal the end of the fiscal responsibility that has briefly renewed investor confidence in Brazil (at least relative to previous administrations). It seems unlikely that Boslonaro would fire Guedes, as it would worsen economic/political instability in the country with little benefit; Boslonaro has already shown that he can overrule Guedes on policy, so firing Guedes has few practical advantages.
- Guedes and his team are currently working on the revamp of Renda Brazil (the main social program in Brazil); they are not expected to release their proposal until next year, and it seems unlikely that Guedes would voluntarily leave before then.  To be honest, I have no idea how to weight these different components quantitatively. That said, I figure the probability of him leaving back in April (when the speculation about his departure reached its peak) was 1/3 at a maximum. There are only two ways for him to leave: resign or be fired. Because firing Guedes would destabilize the tenuous balance Bolsonaro has struck both politically and economically over the past few months, it seems very unlikely that Bolsonaro will fire Guedes. I'd estimate it to be 10%, which mainly corresponds to the possibility that the economy significantly worsens over the next few months. Guedes also seems relatively unlikely to leave on his own accord; there are no major obstacles on the horizon that could reignite his tensions with the president, he is currently revamping Renda Brazil, and he has already suffered several major policy defeats without resigning or making a spectacle. It seems that if he were going to resign, he already would have. I put the probability of him leaving at roughly 1/3 the probability in April, so 11%.
Guedes is more isolated than ever before. Does he have the will to fight indefinitely and be reliant on variables. Didn't quite do justice for the resignations earlier this month.

The superminister of the economy, Guedes, has announced that the more or less #2 official on his team, the Secretary of the National Treasury, one Mansueto Almeida, will be leaving soon, perhaps next month. For those who read Brazilian Portuguese, here is a link https://www.poder360.com.br/economia/mansueto-diz-que-deixara-a-secretaria-do-tesouro-nacional-nos-proximos-meses/ Mansueto, according to reports, made it known several months ago thah he wants out will stay on to help with the "transition."   The person whoa Guedes tapped for the job, Bruno Funchal, has worked closely with Mansueto as head of "he "secretariat" of Mansueto's Secretary of the Treasury quase-ministry. Consider, against the backdrop of the departure of the respected Mansueto after 3 years + on the job,  that the US Treasury has just released its latest TIC data, that indicates the amount of US Trasury instruments held by "foreign countries" (governments, investors, proxies, fronts yatta yatta).   The new TIC reportIn  link https://ticdata.treasury.gov/Publish/mfh.txt  shows that Brazil, or whoever the Treasury in Washington classifies as Brazil, the government, private banks, money market operators, hedge fund tyros, others who may act as fronts or proxies, that during  the "current" month analysed (end April to end March "window"), Brazil has dumped another $4.9 billion in US Treasury instruments, which amounds to a little over 20 billion Reais at the current (5.15 more or less) exchange rate.  Now, add that $4.9 to the agreggate from "last month's TIC data,   (TIC report link https://ticdata.treasury.gov/Publish/mfh.txt ) and what you will see in black and white is that Brazil interests dumped $21 billion in US Treasury instruments between end of Feb. and Mar. of this year. Carry that total ($26 billion) back to the end of August 2019s year and you will note that from end of August to end of January this year, Brazil has sold roughly $27.5 billion for a total of $53.5 of its US Treasury holdings on Guedes' and Mansueto's and the Central Bank's watch (the bank operates quase-independently as part of "his" (technicarally Bolsonaro's) economy superministry.  Brazil media has not been "following the money" so to speak. Nor  has Brasilia offered explanation for the drawdown of $53.5 billion in US Treasury instruments since August last year, roughly 267bilion reais at an aggregate 5.0-$1 rate). That total in itself represents  more than the  total Treasury holds of each of the follwoing nations, Israel, Mexico, Italy, and the Nethands.  Hardly Friedmanesque...  Funchal's image in the media projects as from a younger, post-Guedes, generation, like some of the other youthful ministers and second echelon secretaries the Bolsonaros team has  been embedding into his governing mechanism. For now, treasury is his job to lose.  But these are not normal times in Brazil especially when the current president likes to override ministerial decisions.  Guedes' future as superminister has much to do  with how much he chooses to play ball with the praetorian guard that protects Bolsonaro (a man currently without a political party) working from their offices near his in the Planalto presidential palace. They too have their own (sometime divergent views on how the economy should be "norteado" (Portuguese for, to find its true north) through the continuing crisis. Then too, Guedes' future could be influenced by the Bolsonaro family "guru" the philsopher-astrologer known as Olavo de Carvalho.  Olavo's social media rantings issued from his lair, outside Richmond, Virginia (where he has lived for a decade) Olavo's tirades could have a role in making or breaking the future of Guedes.  Or at least help set up his "fritura" (being fired in Brazilian-Portuguese jargon) as the latest fall guy for Brazil's economic crisis. Yet another problem that could cause collateral damage to the superminister Guedes is the "transparency" (aka "cook the books" accounting) that the international media and some NGOs (all commies or socialists sem duvida) have uncovered in Brazil  surrounding the Health Ministery and state health ministries and Covid-19 pandemia.  Ratings agencies may decide to drill down on whether such shenanigans could it be going on at the Economy Ministry too?   The person who still has the most credibility with the international banking and financial markets, and among central bankers, is not Guedes, it is still Henrique Meirelles, former Economy Minister and former president of Central Bank of Brazil.  He currently serves as economy minister of Sao Paulo state which remains the economic driver of Brazil's economy.  And since he was appointed by governor Joao Doria (who behaves sometimes like he is a Berlusconi clone) he is suspect, since the Bolsonaro clan regards Doria as a potential threat to the reelection plans of "the captain." And with that second term, the continuation of what is showing clear signs of being another classic Latin American process of "national reorganization."  Flip a coin.

In a note released this Tuesday (May 12, 2020), the folder tries to minimize the effects of the speech of Special Secretary Carlos da Costa (Productivity, Employment and Competitiveness), who on Monday, in live, had said that the government is studying  extend the program. As part of the "fritura" (the frying or pre-firing  process in Brazilian Portuguese political slang) process, the current president is distancing himself from the fact that the second phase of Brasil's COVID-19 stimulus package to needy citizens is being held up and as of now, no date as to when these funds will be made available has been set. "ask Guedes" is the generic reply from the presidency, that one finds in online media and on social media. One could view that as "throwing someone under the bus."  An image of Guedes wearing a mask at a photo-op where the president and some others serving in his cabinet were not wearing mask went viral. This could be interpreted by some among the presidency as Guedes, wittingly showing disrespect for the "chain of command." Then too, the president and those close to him wear masks on occasion to palliate critics.  It all might turn on what happens during the US presidential election campaign, who wins, and whether Brazil will need to start printing money and fund up social programs, which are an anethema to the "Chicago school" (and closet Hayekistas) that Guedes was chosen by the president's "transition team" to represent.  Not even the "mas Mies menos Marx" guerrilla grafitti campaign one sees stenciled on the sides of buildings in some major urban areas are going to help.  When, not if.
Bolsonaro is alienating everyone around him, even old allies and given the economic damage due to Covid-19 he'll need someone to throw under the bus.

Because I made a keyboard error on my previous forecast. I think there is at this time a 73 percent chance Guedes will not be Brazil's Minister of the Economy on 1 Dec 2020.

Guedes was appointed in 1/1/19, at the beginning of the Bolsonaro term. It appears that over the last 30 years, slightly less than two-thirds of individuals in this post were replaced within 23 months of appointment (which would be his tenure at the end of the time-period in question). I can see reasons to increase or decrease due to certain "inside view" factors, but they generally cancel each other out. Sticking with the base rate.

Politics being anti-inductive and the press privileging hypothesis, I'm going with a 40%, though it feels more like a 30%. That being said, I expect to update this. Here is a link to Bolsonaro's cabinet: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolsonaro_administration_cabinet_members

De facto, the military rules Brazil. Guedes is not calling the shots on most of the economic issues anymore [1]. It may be too risky for Bolsonaro to officially sack him at the moment, so if Guedes does not resign by himself, I don't think Bolsonaro will fire him. That said, up until now he remains an influential minister, at least due to the financial market [2,3]. He may hold on for a few months to see if he can make a comeback as his economic approach may be in demand again if the economic crisis prevails.
